nonMonitoredImpact.title: Non-monitored Impact
nonMonitoredImpact.subtitle: These outcomes are natural by-products of the primary impact above, but will not be measured or verified.

landManagementActions.title: Land Management Actions
landManagementActions.subtitle: This is how the project developers are planning to achieve the primary impact.

projects.name: Woodburn
glanceText: Increased soil organic carbon concentration to 3.4%.
Improved co-benefits with Soil Health ranking as good, Ecosystem Health as good, and Animal Welfare as excellent.

developer.name: Impact Ag Partners
developer.description: Impact Ag Partners is a specialist agricultural asset management firm and advisory service which utilises a variety of pathways and partners to measure and monitise natural capital.

steward.name: Wilmot Cattle Co.
steward.description: Wilmot Cattle Company is an innovative, regenerative, grass-fed beef business.

broker.name: Regen Network Development, Inc.
broker.description: Regen Network realigns the agricultural economy with ecological health by creating the global marketplace for planetary stewardship.

projects.tagline: Grant and Tanya Wickham have managed Woodburn since 2011

quote.text: We like to run our cattle at a high-density rate, then let the grass come back, usually giving each paddock 60 days rest before the cattle come back.

projects.shortDescription: Woodburn is a 2,555 ha beef breeding enterprise situated north of Walcha on the New England tablelands. Woodburn was purchased in 2011 with the goal of breeding our own homegrown grass-fed beef. Set at approximately 1,120m above sea level with an average annual rainfall of 730mm, the soils are basalt and sandy loam, and the land is lightly timbered.
projects.longDescription:
Grant has been managing Woodburn since it was purchased by the Wilmot Cattle Co in 2011 and has overseen the transition from conventional management systems to regenerative agricultural practices. Grant and Tanya both have an innate connection to the land having come from rural NSW Mid North Coast. Grant has worked in the North West Slopes and Plains region in a managerial role bringing over 25 years experience to the team.

Grant has overseen the conversion of Woodburn's management strategies towards regenerative agricultural practices. This process accelerated from 2016 and has led to a general improvement in the farm's productivity and ecosystem health.
keyOutcomesActivities: Independently verified
Unique - avoiding double issuance through GIS tracking
Real - GHG impact is quantifiable and verifiable
Measurable - each credit represents one ton of CO2e
Permanent - 25 year period through reversal buffer or covenant
Additional - a new practice adopted from pre-approved list
Leakage - de minimis in agricultural land management

actions.name: Time Controlled Rotational Grazing
actions.description: Since 2013, Wilmot Cattle Co has implemented time controlled rotational grazing at Woodburn. Effectively mimicking natural herding behaviours, time controlled rotational grazing is the practice of moving large herds of animals across the landscape, grazing pastures for very short periods of time, allowing long rest periods, enabling adequate plant recovery. Stocking rate is adjusted frequently to match the feed available and growth rate of the plant. When managed well, this grazing system increases groundcover, biomass, plant diversity, animal and plant nutrition, soil health, water infiltration and soil organic carbon.

actions.name: Decrease Paddock Size
actions.description: Decreased paddock sizes enable effective grazing at a controllable density. Woodburn has adopted a paddock subdivision program with an average paddock size of 22 hectares.

actions.name: Increase Stock Density
actions.description: Carefully managed, high stock densities lead to evenly grazed pastures, nutrient recycling, increases in pasture health and performance by trampling (or recycling) a higher proportion of biomass, and evenly distributing dung and urine (nutrients).

actions.name: Monitor Pasture Growth
actions.description: Accurate measurement of pasture growth (available feed) determines the density of animals and length of time in a paddock.

actions.name: Manage Grazing Periods
actions.description: To ensure effectively implemented grazing practices and management practices records, Woodburn utilizes the online tool Maia Grazing. Maia Grazing uses climatic data and field observations to determine pasture growth and optimal stocking rates, tracks stock movements, and ensures the stocking rate does not exceed the carrying capacity of each paddock.

impact.name: Soil Organic Carbon
impact.description: Organic matter contributes to nutrient retention and turnover, soil structure, moisture retention and availability, degradation of pollutants, carbon sequestration and soil resilience.

impact.name: Animal Welfare
impact.description: Animal welfare is an important component in a well managed grazing enterprise. Low stress stock handling techniques have been adopted to ensure animals have higher quality life.

impact.name: Ecosystem Health
impact.description: In the ecological realm, ‘health’ is characterized by system integrity and the exhibition of certain fundamental properties of self-organizing complex systems.

impact.name: Soil Health
impact.description: The capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.

creditClass.name: CarbonPlus Grasslands
creditClass.description:
Livestock grazing covers over 3.3 billion hectares, or 25 percent of the world’s land area. Managed grazing practices can reverse land degradation, enhance net carbon sequestration, and improve soil and vegetation quality.

Under managed grazing, carbon sequestration potential is estimated between 16.4 and 26 Gt CO2e sequestered in the period between 2020-2050.

This credit is designed to significantly increase the amount of hectares under managed grazing worldwide. To that end, the methodology relies on remote sensing to substantially reduce the cost of monitoring carbon sequestration while maintaining scientific rigor.

projects.name: Wongella

developer.name: Impact Ag Partners
developer.description: Impact Ag Partners is a specialist agricultural asset management firm and advisory service which utilises a variety of pathways and partners to measure and monitise natural capital.

steward.name: Wongella
steward.description: Wongella specialises in producing high quality livestock in a managment system that supports sustainble agroecological outcomes.

broker.name: Regen Network Development, Inc.
broker.description: Regen Network realigns the agricultural economy with ecological health by creating the global marketplace for planetary stewardship.

projects.tagline: Dan Carney has managed Wongella with his operations team since 2017

quote.text: A holistic focus and ensuring our Land comes first has paid dividends through two very dry years. We have been able to turn what traditionally would have been an ecological and economic negative into a positive. Through strategic grazing and stock management we’ve more than doubled our carrying capacity while improving pasture composition and soil health.

projects.shortDescription: Wongella is a 3,916 hectare property located in the South Burnett region of Queensland, Australia. At the time of purchase in 2017, the property was heavily degraded and the current management team set out to restore and regenerate the landscape while producing climate friendly grass fed beef.
projects.longDescription:
Dan Carney and the Wongella team understand the needs of a landscape starts with a custodial approach, one that embraces the whole system and speaks of the interactive relationship of soil, water, plants and animals. At Wongella the journey to restoration began with embracing this approach and applying practices and principles of regenerative agriculture to realise the potential for a sustainable eco-agricultural production enterprise.

These keystone practices centre on enhancing on-farm soil health and plant biodiversity, minimising the use of synthetic chemical and fertiliser use, minimising soil disturbance, maximising year-round ground cover and the introduction of time-controlled (regenerative) livestock grazing.
keyOutcomesActivities: Independently verified
Unique - avoiding double issuance through GIS tracking
Real - GHG impact is quantifiable and verifiable
Measurable - each credit represents one ton of CO2e
Permanent - 25 year period through reversal buffer or covenant
Additional - a new practice adopted from pre-approved list
Leakage - de minimis in agricultural land management

actions.name: Time Controlled Rotational Grazing
actions.description: The livestock grazing management system practiced at Wongella is characterised by high stocking densities with rotations of short duration followed by long restoration periods for optimal pasture recovery. With the one-herd approach made up of 400-600 head, the 1-2 day seasonally dependent moves mean the cattle are grazing each paddock between 6-8 days/year, giving the land a 97% window to restore cover and convert rainfall into nutritional feed. This method is seasonally adaptive with proven benefits including increased soil fertility and water holding capacity, increased pasture density, composition and complexity, improved animal health and has led to increased stocking rates.  In addition, building the landscapes capacity for restoration provides the added security needed for making decisions that match stocking rates with land carrying capacity, with latest reports confirming Wongella stocking rates are double that of the South Burnett district’s average.

projects.name: Cavan Station

developer.name: Impact Ag Partners
developer.description: Impact Ag Partners is a specialist agricultural asset management firm and advisory service which utilises a variety of pathways and partners to measure and monitise natural capital.

steward.name: Cavan Station
steward.description: Cavan Station specialises in producing the highest quality Merino sheep, wool, lamb and beef utilising sustainable management systems.

broker.name: Regen Network Development, Inc.
broker.description: Regen Network realigns the agricultural economy with ecological health by creating the global marketplace for planetary stewardship.

projects.tagline: Matt Crozier has managed Cavan Station since 2011 with a full time staff of nine

quote.text: The most recent drought experience has highlighted how Cavan can still be profitable and productive, while generating positive ecological outcomes even through the dry years.

projects.shortDescription: Cavan Station is a 9,900 hectare aggregation of properties divided by the Murrunbidgee River at Yass, on the southern tablelands of NSW. Cavan comprises a diverse range of landscapes including limestone rocky outcrops, undulating slopes and steep native vegetated hills.
projects.longDescription:
The need to build adaptability and resilience into an iconic Merino enterprise has taken a traditional, large scale business on a successful change management journey, building economic, social, and ecological capital through 'enlightened stewardship' and a major rethink on how the business manages its land.

Cavan Station is focused on the production of the highest-quality, humanely certified merino wool along with lamb and beef. Cavan is also home to the Bogo Merino Stud, producing premium Merino genetics.
keyOutcomesActivities: Independently verified
Unique - avoiding double issuance through GIS tracking
Real - GHG impact is quantifiable and verifiable
Measurable - each credit represents one ton of CO2e
Permanent - 25 year period through reversal buffer or covenant
Additional - a new practice adopted from pre-approved list
Leakage - de minimis in agricultural land management

actions.name: Time Controlled Rotational Grazing
actions.description: Building a resilient and adaptive business to withstand future climatic, environmental, social and economic challenges was the core focus for Cavan's investment in change. Cavan has been able to build ecological capital during seasonally tough periods, with a steady upward trend in soil organic carbon levels. By focusing on the landscape and the management of grazing systems, improvements in animal welfare and productivity have been realised. Matching stocking rate to carrying capacity, maintaining ground cover, implementing rotational grazing, increasing productivity of pastures and managing feed budgets with the Maia Grazing management tool has resulted in an overall improvement to productivity, profitability and ecological health.

projects.name: Wilmot
glanceText: Increased soil organic carbon concentration to 4.5%.
Improved co-benefits significantly with Soil Health ranking as excellent, Ecosystem Health as good, and Animal Welfare as excellent.

developer.name: Impact Ag Partners
developer.description: Impact Ag Partners is a specialist agricultural asset management firm and advisory service which utilises a variety of pathways and partners to measure and monitise natural capital.

steward.name: Wilmot Cattle Co.
steward.description: Wilmot Cattle Company is an innovative, regenerative, grass-fed beef business.

broker.name: Regen Network Development, Inc.
broker.description: Regen Network realigns the agricultural economy with ecological health by creating the global marketplace for planetary stewardship.

projects.tagline: Stuart Austin & Trisha Cowley have managed Wilmot since 2016

quote.text: We feel privileged to have the opportunity to manage cattle in a truly holistic and regenerative way on such a remarkable property.

projects.shortDescription: Wilmot is an extraordinary property high in the New England Tablelands at Ebor, New South Wales, Australia. Set on 1,854ha and at approximately 1,200m above sea level, average annual rainfall of 1,200mm, highly fertile volcanic basalt soils, and complimented by a series of pristine spring fed, year-round natural waterways including five waterfalls, it is quite simply a unique environment for growing cattle.
projects.longDescription:
Stu & Trish are the management team behind Wilmot Cattle Co and are driven by the exciting ecological opportunities they can foresee for the business. They have a wholehearted belief in regenerative agriculture and the benefits it will bring to the industry globally, as we collectively work to heal what has largely become a degraded landscape. They have a burning desire to succeed in agriculture and are very ambitious in the growth and development plans they have for Wilmot Cattle Co.

While Stu has managed the day to day operations of Wilmot since 2016, and now presides over the portfolio of all three properties in a General Manager capacity, Trish works tirelessly behind the scenes ensuring a high level of rigor around the data collection, management, and analysis of every aspect of the business. They firmly believe that you cannot manage what you do not measure and as such, the integrity of the data is paramount.

In their spare time, they enjoy exploring the natural wonders of Wilmot, including its five waterfalls and large areas of virtually native bushland, with their two kids Harry and Poppy. They all gain great satisfaction from discovering new species of plants and learning about their role in the ecosystem.

actions.name: Time Controlled Rotational Grazing
actions.description: Since 2013, Wilmot Cattle Co. has implemented time controlled rotational grazing at Wilmot Farm. In order to mirror natural herding behaviors, time controlled rotational grazing optimizes the number of stock in a paddock, matches the grazing period with available pasture, shortens grazing periods in each paddock, and follows these activities by long resting periods to allow the pasture to recover. When managed well, this grazing system increases groundcover, biomass, plant diversity, animal and plant nutrition, soil health, water infiltration and soil organic carbon.

actions.description: To ensure effectively implemented grazing practices and management practices records, Wilmot Farm utilizes the online tool Maia Grazing. projects.name: Pillango
glanceText: Implementing regenerative agriculture and rewilding land to restore grasslands and rebuild carbon stocks.

developer.name: The Provenance Co.
developer.description: The Provenance Co. partners with impact investors to deliver climate resilience with investor worthy returns by unleashing the awesome carbon sequestering power of America’s Great Plains.

broker.name: Regen Network Development, Inc.
broker.description: Regen Network realigns the agricultural economy with ecological health by creating the global marketplace for planetary stewardship.

projects.tagline: The Provenance Co. is leading the Pillango Project to restore its carbon sequestering capacity

quote.text: Restoring health to agricultural land and economies goes hand-in-hand with restoring local and indigenous rural communities. This is the story of the Pillango Project.  Restoring Pillango will be a journey filled with hard work, high emotions, and dusty days, and I am thrilled to have the opportunity to learn what the potential of this awesome landscape can be.

person.name: Julie Mettenburg
person.role: The Provenance Co., Head of Land Regeneration

projects.shortDescription: The Pillango Project is a 1,101 hectare landscape rooted in an area that was once the world's second largest temperate indigenous grassland, the Great Plains of the U.S. Located in Wallace County, Kansas, Pillango resides at an altitude of 1,059m above sea level and receives an average annual rainfall of approximately 508mm. Pillango is situated in an area of the U.S. that has geographic significance due to its location above the Ogallala Aquifer, a vital water source that is rapidly depleting. In its original prairie form, the landscape was a herbaceous grassland rooted with native shortgrass prairie perennials. Over the last ten to fifteen years, the land has been cultivated as dryland corn and wheat. This has led to soil degradation, characterized by diminished carbon and water storage capacity. Despite this, the landscape has produced cropland-worthy yields under low rainfall conditions for multiple years, illustrating the underlying potential of its native soil bed.
projects.longDescription:
When Pillango’s owner Will sought to transition his Kansas cropland into climate beneficial production in 2019, he partnered with The Provenance Co (TPC). TPC is led by founders Julie and Leslie, siblings who grew up raising livestock on Kansas land. Julie and Leslie bring their institutional knowledge of regenerative agriculture and on-the-ground management experience to bear on the two biggest challenges properties like Pillango face when transitioning: degraded soil and lack of infrastructure to sustain animal, human and microbial life. Together, Will, Julie, and Leslie have been united in the philosophy that in order to restore life underground, one must simultaneously restore life above ground. TPC began implementing their proprietary land stewardship protocol, Regenerative Rewilding ®, in January of 2021.

In June of 2020, TPC began to work towards returning both human and animal life to Pillango. Jodi, an experienced farming practitioner raised on the fierce Western Kansas landscape, is the onsite crew leader. Dan, trained as an organic soil specialist, and Roberto, an expert herdsman with 20+ years of ranching experience, oversee livestock movement across Pillango land. Together, Jodi, Dan, and Roberto marry animal impact with soil restoration to rebuild the land's carbon sequestration stores. The onsite TPC team also includes Dan's wife, Cole, and their two children.
keyOutcomesActivities: Independently verified
Unique - avoiding double issuance through GIS tracking
Real - GHG impact is quantifiable and verifiable
Measurable - each credit represents one ton of CO2e
Permanent - 25 year period through reversal buffer or covenant
Additional - a new practice adopted from pre-approved list
Leakage - de minimis in agricultural land management

actions.name: Regenerative agriculture
actions.description: The Provenance Co’s proprietary Regenerative Rewilding® protocol implements the five principles of Regenerative Agriculture: Minimize soil disturbance, maximize crop diversity, keep the soil covered, maintain living roots year-round, and integrate livestock.

actions.name: Rewilding
actions.description: The Provenance Co’s proprietary Regenerative Rewilding® protocl uses wild herd behaviour and dynamics as a model for agricultural production. The protocol aims to mimic key elements of wild herd activity to physically work the soil, as required for regeneration. Doing so allows TPC to achieve the animal concentration required to jumpstart sequestering mechanisms in the soil, in a manner that honors the animal's instinctive nature.

actions.name: Risk Management
actions.description: The Provenance Co’s proprietary Regenerative Rewilding® protocol aims to reduce the financial risk farming poses while optimizing carbon sequestration. When captured and measured, carbon stores can be monetized, offsetting some financial risk for farmers. Marrying carbon sequestration outcomes to land productivity and financial health allows TPC to better align systemic farming risk with real climate impact.
